source_contexts: BD037: So I guess the other group I would think about, of stakeholders, you know, inherent in this system are resource managers, NOAA fisheries, stocks assessment scientists and things like that

Ok, so I think we’re done with key food-webs supporting species, so if organisms harmful to humans were to increase, how would that impact the system?

BD037: So, I see weak relationships between increases in harmful organisms to humans and the top two boxes, so, um, yeah
So if gamma scale diversity would increase, you know, shark species diversity would increase as would key food-web supporting species, harmful organisms to humans, and species of conservation concern

Um, anything else for harmful organisms?

BD037: No
Interviewer 1: Do you think it would be - I know we have harmful organisms to humans
Positive relationship with harmful organisms to humans
Same with harmful organisms, and same with food-web supporting species
But the four components are habitat forming species, species of conservation concern, harmful organisms, and key food-web supporting species
Um, medium weights between key food-web supporting species and harmful organisms
Positive strong relationship to species diversity, geographic scale diversity, food-web supporting species, no relationship to harmful organisms
Um, harmful organisms, you know, a bit
I don’t really - I see a weak relationship, I guess, between key food-web supporting species and harmful organisms

And that’s - we’re, uh, [Interviewer 2]’s doing some interviews with tourism operators as well, and so we’re hoping to have representation from the tourism industry and the fishing industry to talk about just that
Or for the stakeholders

BD037: I guess I should probably clarify, when I say fishing stakeholders, you know, I think there’s a pretty big difference between recreational fishing stakeholders, charter fishing stakeholders, and commercial fishermen
Yeah, I think what I spend a lot of time thinking about recently is how increases in species of conservation concern have negative impacts, or potential for negative impacts on stakeholders
So those stakeholders are sort of forced to deal through those scenarios before the fishermen managers are
So, since we still have a few minutes, I wanted to ask if there are specific ecosystem services that are related to this system? Or stakeholders that are affected by the system
BD037: So I guess the other group I would think about, of stakeholders, you know, inherent in this system are resource managers, NOAA fisheries, stocks assessment scientists and things like that

Um, I think I mentioned this to [Interviewer 2], you know, these Australian guys that deal with the same issue have proposed and subsequently have funded this series of workshops to address deprivation in Australia and they’ve, you know, they’ve invited me to attend those workshops as someone who knows how to use mental modeler
So it depends on the audience that you’re around, but fishermen talk a lot about that
But then, it’s almost as if the very true fishermen don’t have the desire to see that because it adversely impacts their experiences on the water
I mean it’s the same sort of negative interactions that are sort of plaguing fishermen
But, yeah, it’s a pretty, it’s a pretty topical issue among fishermen
And I think that human-wildlife conflict and, um, I can see that relationship pretty clearly

But worthwhile to add in human-wildlife conflict as a separate concept, just conceptually? Or is that too redundant?

BD037: Um, no, I don’t think it’s too redundant
Is there anything else? Should we go back quickly to the, yeah, to the resource managers
BD037: So I guess the other group I would think about, of stakeholders, you know, inherent in this system are resource managers, NOAA fisheries, stocks assessment scientists and things like that
And, medium for - well, a low weight for species conservation concern

So, SEDAR, you know the South Eastern Data Assessment Review, the stock assessment process essentially, SEDAR 77 - I’m a part of that process right now and that encompasses all hammerheads in the Atlantic Ocean
Same with the SEDAR 77 report card, that’s a negative relationship as would the other two boxes honestly, EBFM and multi-species management
It was something I haven’t seen from the previous SEDARs

And I think with respect to the orange areas, like starting on the left hand side and moving down, I would say… a high level of difficulty, same with the SEDAR 77 report cards, and then medium, a medium strength relationship between the final two

Um, should we make a note? So, if I understood correctly, within SEDAR 77, the component that might, or that’s starting to consider biodiversity was those report cards of species interactions? Is that right?

BD037: Yes
So all coastal sharks managed in the same management plan, and even sometimes assessed through the same SEDAR

So, SEDAR, you know the South Eastern Data Assessment Review, the stock assessment process essentially, SEDAR 77 - I’m a part of that process right now and that encompasses all hammerheads in the Atlantic Ocean
And then, the blue are either current management strategies or policies, so single species management and SEDAR 77, that are kind of considering biodiversity but not explicitly
With respect to, you know, the more species, SEDAR 77 single species management, things like that, it’s kind of that same concept
And then, you know, I would say a slightly positive relationship to the SEDAR 77 box and the single species management
Same with the SEDAR 77 report card, that’s a negative relationship as would the other two boxes honestly, EBFM and multi-species management

And I think with respect to the orange areas, like starting on the left hand side and moving down, I would say… a high level of difficulty, same with the SEDAR 77 report cards, and then medium, a medium strength relationship between the final two

Um, should we make a note? So, if I understood correctly, within SEDAR 77, the component that might, or that’s starting to consider biodiversity was those report cards of species interactions? Is that right?

BD037: Yes

So, SEDAR, you know the South Eastern Data Assessment Review, the stock assessment process essentially, SEDAR 77 - I’m a part of that process right now and that encompasses all hammerheads in the Atlantic Ocean
And then, the blue are either current management strategies or policies, so single species management and SEDAR 77, that are kind of considering biodiversity but not explicitly

BD037: I guess I should probably clarify, when I say fishing stakeholders, you know, I think there’s a pretty big difference between recreational fishing stakeholders, charter fishing stakeholders, and commercial fishermen

And then we’re going to use that framework in our workshop in a more localized use with specific species of interest, whether or not that’s a fisheries target species or oysters for aquaculture, or living shorelines
of the work where they have population segments that are experiencing overfishing
Um, so, some of our team’s previous work has generalized four key components of marine biodiversity as we’re attempting to conceptualize and define biodiversity

And then, the key food-web supporting species, you know, I think a lot of, I would say almost all of the sharks I study are considered meso-predators, so kind of squarely in the middle tier of a food-web
So age, growth, reproduction, maturation, a fair bit of trophic ecology work

Because, you know, if those species are key food-web supporting species, I feel like there’s an inherently better understanding of their trophic ecology, so that makes that a bit, perhaps cleaner to examine in that framework, that multi-species framework

Would you say that your preferred state of species of conservation concern is increase or decrease? How are you think about that? How are you thinking about that as you’re building up this model?

BD037: So when I think about - I think about something like a sandbar shark for example

Um, should we make a note? So, if I understood correctly, within SEDAR 77, the component that might, or that’s starting to consider biodiversity was those report cards of species interactions? Is that right?

BD037: Yes
But the four components are habitat forming species, species of conservation concern, harmful organisms, and key food-web supporting species
So, sort of habitat forming species -  I don’t tend to rank that very highly just because it doesn’t lend itself to the types of organisms I study

And then, the key food-web supporting species, you know, I think a lot of, I would say almost all of the sharks I study are considered meso-predators, so kind of squarely in the middle tier of a food-web
Same with harmful organisms, and same with food-web supporting species
But the four components are habitat forming species, species of conservation concern, harmful organisms, and key food-web supporting species
Key food-web supporting species
Positive strong relationship to species diversity, geographic scale diversity, food-web supporting species, no relationship to harmful organisms
With respect to, you know, the more species, SEDAR 77 single species management, things like that, it’s kind of that same concept
And then, you know, I would say a slightly positive relationship to the SEDAR 77 box and the single species management
And… a positive relationship to single species management
And so that actually increases the impetus for their single species management
And then, our last one is single species management
Increases in single species management positively increase species of conservation concern and, let’s see… positive relationships between the three other management options
And then, the blue are either current management strategies or policies, so single species management and SEDAR 77, that are kind of considering biodiversity but not explicitly

So, if there’s an increase in key food-web supporting species, I think when it comes to multi-species management, that if that relationship is understood, I think that’s an easier thing to model or an easier thing to capture, in both the interspecies model for an ecosystem based fishery model
Ok, so the arrow to multi-species management I see is positive with a medium weight, same with EBFM

So this is to say if there was increase in a shark that was dangerous to humans, I mean I think that could be well captured in something like a multi-species management plan or a fisheries-based management plan

And then for the four bottom boxes, that makes things like EBFM and multi-species management a bit more of a challenge, and I say that because a lot of these species of conservation concern, we just don’t know very much about their life history
So, I think to finish that box, for me the other relationships I see are with multi-species management and EBFM

So, the, if we increased multi-species management approaches, how would that increase the system?

BD037: I think that’s a positive relationship with species of conservation concern

So, great hammerhead, scalloped hammerhead, and carolina hammerhead, and we have been filling out kind of report cards, essentially, that look at how those animals interact with other species and their potential vulnerabilities to changes in their populations

Um, should we make a note? So, if I understood correctly, within SEDAR 77, the component that might, or that’s starting to consider biodiversity was those report cards of species interactions? Is that right?

BD037: Yes

And I think with respect to the orange areas, like starting on the left hand side and moving down, I would say… a high level of difficulty, same with the SEDAR 77 report cards, and then medium, a medium strength relationship between the final two

Um, and so, one of the first things that we learned during this project is that the term biodiversity means different things to different people, and obviously it can be measured in multiple different ways
To understand these issues, of how to frame biodiversity and how to conceptualize it, for a potential decision making framework
The orange boxes are the ways that you personally think about biodiversity, so species diversity of sharks, and then kind of regional scale diversity
So, we’re wondering, like I said, how - we’re trying to assess if and how we manage for biodiversity in US management
Um, so those gray boxes in the center are those bins that we’ve identified as the aspects of biodiversity
So, actually I think a bit about biodiversity with respect to the work which I do

Are there approaches or policies that you would like to see to better manage for biodiversity?

BD037: You know, we talk a lot about the concepts of multi-species management and ecosystem approaches to fisheries, and ecosystem based fishery management

But then, if you continue along that sort of trajectory, I see the potential to add things like sharks into more - at least simple ecosystem based management approaches and I think, you know, as complicated as that might be, I think there are inherent benefits for biodiversity if those plans can be implemented successfully
And then, the blue are either current management strategies or policies, so single species management and SEDAR 77, that are kind of considering biodiversity but not explicitly
And so, we’re wondering if you agree with those key components of biodiversity, and if not, how you would change it
So, when I think about biodiversity, I tend to think about it from that perspective
Is not as though the biodiversity has really changed that much
And you’d be a fan of multi-species management that might more explicitly consider biodiversity if they were implemented
And so to start, I’m wondering if you think that biodiversity is currently explicitly considered in management, and if so, with what approaches or policies
Um, the really high level overarching goal - the project is to understand how experts think about biodiversity and how we manage for biodiversity in US marine resource management
So, I know that you are very familiar with mental modeler, for this project we’re using mental modeler to understand how management impacts biodiversity and other system components
Um, so, some of our team’s previous work has generalized four key components of marine biodiversity as we’re attempting to conceptualize and define biodiversity
Um, and so as a starting point today, we are hoping to hear what you see as the key aspects of biodiversity and what you think about when you think about biodiversity

Um, should we make a note? So, if I understood correctly, within SEDAR 77, the component that might, or that’s starting to consider biodiversity was those report cards of species interactions? Is that right?

BD037: Yes

Um, so, kind of landing the plane on that thought, when I think of biodiversity, I tend to think about species level diversity with respect to our area, which for me North Central Gulf of Mexico, like, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama

But no, I mean, the bulk of the assessments, or I guess, all of the assessments that I’ve ever been a part of, maybe 15 or so, all approach management of marine resources from a single species standpoint
It’s essentially this concept that, I mean, think about marine turtles
So if gamma scale diversity would increase, you know, shark species diversity would increase as would key food-web supporting species, harmful organisms to humans, and species of conservation concern

Are there, um, key issues in the Northern Gulf of Mexico that you think are relevant to this project and important for us to maybe hone-in on in this workshop?

BD037: I mean again, I spend so much time thinking about shark deprivation
There’s a, you know, a strong positive relationship between multiple species management and ecosystem-based fishery management, um, and really no relationship to the - well, let me think about that

BD037: I guess I should probably clarify, when I say fishing stakeholders, you know, I think there’s a pretty big difference between recreational fishing stakeholders, charter fishing stakeholders, and commercial fishermen
I wanted to just really quickly, before we go on… so you said if species of conservation concern were to increase, that would increase, in this example with sharks, organisms harmful to humans
That said, species of conservation concern, that is always kind of front and center when I think about sharks, and increasingly for rays
Yeah, I think what I spend a lot of time thinking about recently is how increases in species of conservation concern have negative impacts, or potential for negative impacts on stakeholders

But I think, you know there’s a positive relationship as recreational - as species of conservation concern are increased, I think that there’s a positive relationship to recreational fishermen, but less so for charter-for-higher, and even less so for commercial
But the four components are habitat forming species, species of conservation concern, harmful organisms, and key food-web supporting species

So then, the SEDAR report cards, if we were to have more report cards and those approaches, how would that impact that system?

BD037: I think that’s good - you know, that increases in a positive way the whole EBFM and ecosystem-based fisheries management, same with species of conservation concern
Increases in single species management positively increase species of conservation concern and, let’s see… positive relationships between the three other management options

So, the, if we increased multi-species management approaches, how would that increase the system?

BD037: I think that’s a positive relationship with species of conservation concern

And so, I’m making sure that I interpret that correctly, what I intend for that is an increase in the prevalence of ecosystem based management would have a strong and positive effect on species of conservation concern
And again, I approach that from a fisheries management standpoint, and that would apply to both fishes and to sharks

Right, so, if you go to South West Florida, you would expect the diversity of the reef fish assemblage there to be 4, 5, 6 times what it is here in the North Central reefs of the Gulf of Mexico where our assemblage is really culminated by a handful of snapper species

Now, the counter to that, when I think about reef fish, because we do a fair bit of work with reef fish, I think about how the species diversity is so different here versus areas like South West Florida, and in exactly the opposite way
And I guess with respect to protected species as well, like with dolphins
There’s people that desire to see those protected species continue to be protected, and the populations recover fully

And that’s - we’re, uh, [Interviewer 2]’s doing some interviews with tourism operators as well, and so we’re hoping to have representation from the tourism industry and the fishing industry to talk about just that
Whenever I’m showing that gear type to them, it always occurs to me that we have a large species diversity here in the North Central Gulf of Mexico

Um, so, kind of landing the plane on that thought, when I think of biodiversity, I tend to think about species level diversity with respect to our area, which for me North Central Gulf of Mexico, like, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama
I wanted to just really quickly, before we go on… so you said if species of conservation concern were to increase, that would increase, in this example with sharks, organisms harmful to humans
And the same applies for sharks, really

Are there approaches or policies that you would like to see to better manage for biodiversity?

BD037: You know, we talk a lot about the concepts of multi-species management and ecosystem approaches to fisheries, and ecosystem based fishery management

So, if there’s an increase in key food-web supporting species, I think when it comes to multi-species management, that if that relationship is understood, I think that’s an easier thing to model or an easier thing to capture, in both the interspecies model for an ecosystem based fishery model

So I work on a variety of species; red snapper, red drum, amberjack, trip and tail, jackerval, this morning… lots of other things, but primarily, I guess the body of my work, most of my work, is focused on coastal sharks
So all coastal sharks managed in the same management plan, and even sometimes assessed through the same SEDAR
So small coastal sharks, large coastal sharks, a little bit of pelagic shark work, but mostly coastal species
A fair bit of movement in migration work, so I’ve been using natural tracers, or we’re typically using telemetry
So acoustic telemetry, or satellite telemetry
So if gamma scale diversity would increase, you know, shark species diversity would increase as would key food-web supporting species, harmful organisms to humans, and species of conservation concern
Um, but a very strong and positive relationship with gamma diversity and species diversity
BD037: Yeah, so an increase in species diversity of sharks would make single-species management of sharks more difficult

So, is it logical for me to be making an increasing or decreasing relationship between species diversity of sharks and things like single-species management?

Interviewer 1: Yeah, however you see that relationship working

Now, the counter to that, when I think about reef fish, because we do a fair bit of work with reef fish, I think about how the species diversity is so different here versus areas like South West Florida, and in exactly the opposite way

And that, that arrow though, between species diversity of sharks and key food-web supporting species, that could be bi-directional?

Interviewer 1: Yep
So, a high weight between species diversity of sharks and then gamma diversity
Species diversity within elasmobranchs
The orange boxes are the ways that you personally think about biodiversity, so species diversity of sharks, and then kind of regional scale diversity
So I’m always quick to point out, if these students were taking this class in New England, for example, or in the Pacific NorthWest, or areas like that, the species diversity would be much lower

So, how would an increase in that impact the rest of these components?

BD037: An increase in the species diversity of sharks?

Interviewer 1: Yeah
Um… I think increasing the species diversity of sharks would in turn increase the potential for those species to be of conservation concern
Positive strong relationship to species diversity, geographic scale diversity, food-web supporting species, no relationship to harmful organisms
Whenever I’m showing that gear type to them, it always occurs to me that we have a large species diversity here in the North Central Gulf of Mexico
So, maybe let’s start with species diversity of sharks

Um, I think I mentioned this to [Interviewer 2], you know, these Australian guys that deal with the same issue have proposed and subsequently have funded this series of workshops to address deprivation in Australia and they’ve, you know, they’ve invited me to attend those workshops as someone who knows how to use mental modeler
Interviewer 2: I do, but I’m not going to pass up a trip to Australia
Now on the other hand I think about sawfish, and things like that
Like you would want a sawfish population to increase

So, I would say that’s kind of one of the central themes of the class, is understanding and appreciating the diversity of a lot of our banks sharks and rays, you know, it could be that within the course of their two week field course, they might see 13 to 15 different species of elasmobranchs
Species diversity within elasmobranchs

So, with that, if those were to increase, how would that impact the system?

BD037: Sure, so I think the first thing - I mean, white sharks were at some point a species of conservation concern
So maybe let’s jump to gamma diversity, the geographic scale concept
So, a high weight between species diversity of sharks and then gamma diversity
Um, but a very strong and positive relationship with gamma diversity and species diversity
Positive strong relationship to species diversity, geographic scale diversity, food-web supporting species, no relationship to harmful organisms
And I guess with respect to protected species as well, like with dolphins

The cool thing about using mental modeler, as you know, is you can run those scenario simulations to look at tradoffs, so the goal is for the second day… we’ll build the model on day 1 and for the second day we’ll use the scenarios to look at how different management interventions would impact these different stakeholders in different ways
When we do see, you know, these hammerheads are a great example
So, I’m a fisheries ecologist
So, I know that you are very familiar with mental modeler, for this project we’re using mental modeler to understand how management impacts biodiversity and other system components

The cool thing about using mental modeler, as you know, is you can run those scenario simulations to look at tradoffs, so the goal is for the second day… we’ll build the model on day 1 and for the second day we’ll use the scenarios to look at how different management interventions would impact these different stakeholders in different ways

Um, I think I mentioned this to [Interviewer 2], you know, these Australian guys that deal with the same issue have proposed and subsequently have funded this series of workshops to address deprivation in Australia and they’ve, you know, they’ve invited me to attend those workshops as someone who knows how to use mental modeler

So then, the SEDAR report cards, if we were to have more report cards and those approaches, how would that impact that system?

BD037: I think that’s good - you know, that increases in a positive way the whole EBFM and ecosystem-based fisheries management, same with species of conservation concern
And, medium for - well, a low weight for species conservation concern
Um… I think increasing the species diversity of sharks would in turn increase the potential for those species to be of conservation concern

The cool thing about using mental modeler, as you know, is you can run those scenario simulations to look at tradoffs, so the goal is for the second day… we’ll build the model on day 1 and for the second day we’ll use the scenarios to look at how different management interventions would impact these different stakeholders in different ways

Are there, um, key issues in the Northern Gulf of Mexico that you think are relevant to this project and important for us to maybe hone-in on in this workshop?

BD037: I mean again, I spend so much time thinking about shark deprivation
We have two other case studies along with the Northern Gulf of Mexico
